Yesterday’s activities and updates included:

- Motion Shading was on-site routing all shade wires to their assigned panel locations on walls.
- Jaime was grading the driveway and cutting the hill out, raising the curb, and performing a concrete pour.
- There was communication about trash and debris on the site and road, with requests to clean up and ensure proper trash disposal.
- A new construction entrance was cut to align with the driveway entrance, with readiness noted for insulation and drywall trucks.
- A 1-inch water meter was installed; during installation, Dekalb hit a Google Fiber line, and Brookhaven officials said a Right of Way permit is required for future water meter installs.
- Final rough review notes from Thomas and Ron Heller covered multiple rooms with tasks such as lift power installation, HDMI cable deployment, moving transformer boxes, adding step lights to the media platform, and other electrical and structural adjustments.
- Electrical work by Yanes included cove lighting, lowering ceiling lights and fans, and solar pipe boot sealing.
- Overhang metal roof and custom drip edge installation was completed.
- Tile placement walkthrough with Freddy and Jeffrey took place.
- Deliveries and cleanup included Ipe wood from Miami and dumpster drop-off; a tow truck and police were involved in resolving the dumpster placement.
- Discussions about the chandelier motor mount, change order estimates sent, and follow-up about ceiling motor mounts.
- Coordination on mounting cameras was needed as battery power was running low.
- The site was noted to be dry with no leaks.

This summary reflects the key points and progress from yesterday on the 1293 Sylvian project site.  

**Source:** "Slack, 2025-05-01"

Yesterday’s activities on the 1293 Sylvian project included:

- Motion Shading was on-site rerouting all shade wires to their panel locations on assigned walls.
- A new construction entrance was cut to align with the driveway entrance, making the area ready for insulation and drywall trucks.
- Jaime worked on grading the driveway and cutting the hill, raising the curb, and preparing for concrete pouring scheduled on Monday.
- There was a site cleanup focus due to trash found on the road and around the property; Gerardo was asked to clean up debris around the outhouse.
- The 1-inch water meter was installed, but during installation, Dekalb hit the Google Fiber line. Brookhaven officials were on-site requiring a ROW permit for future installations.
- Thomas provided notes from the final rough review with Ron Heller, covering various electrical, drywall, and fixture installation points in multiple rooms including the entry foyer, den, bedrooms, kitchen, pantry, media, exterior canopies, and more.
- Yanes Electrical completed all his electrical items except for solar on Tuesday and was on site for added items, adjustments, and reinstallations including vent pipes, outlets, lights, and solar extension.
- The Ipe wood order was delivered, and Nathan Alejandro helped clean the garage and site for unloading.
- The dumpster was on-site with a tow truck needed to fix its placement, police on scene to assist.
- Preparations for the chandelier motor and other change orders were discussed and documented with approvals pending.
- There was a tile placement walkthrough at 2 pm including Freddy and Jeffrey (designer).
- Steel post support and roofing elements like metal roof overhang and drip edge were installed.
- Solar pipe boot seal and roof cap work was completed.

Overall, last day was busy with shading wire rerouting, driveway adjustments, electrical work progress, material deliveries, site cleaning efforts, and preparations for next week’s pours and installations.

(Source: Slack messages, 2025-05-01)
what happened with google fiber?

Regarding Google Fiber, the Slack messages note that during the installation of the 1-inch water meter, Dekalb hit the Google Fiber line. This led to Brookhaven officials stating that a Brookhaven Right of Way (ROW) permit is needed before any future water meter installation. They allowed the current work to proceed but advised obtaining the permit for future installations.

Here is the exact relevant message excerpt:
"1 inch water meter installed yesterday. Dekalb hit the google fiber line. Ended up having 3 Brookhaven officials stating we needed Brookhaven ROW permit prior to water meter install. Said fine now but make sure in the future."

No further details or updates about Google Fiber were found in the available records.

(Source: Slack, 2025-04-29 ET messages)
what happened yesterday?

Yesterday’s key activities and issues at 1293 Sylvian included:

- Motion Shading was on site rerouting all shade wires to their panel locations on assigned walls.
- Jaime worked on grading the driveway, cutting the hill out, raising the curb, and performed a concrete pour.
- A new construction entrance was cut to correspond with the driveway entrance, preparing for insulation and drywall trucks.
- Trash and debris cleanup was a concern, with a neighbor complaint about trash on the road near the property.
- Final rough review notes from Thomas and Ron Heller covered many areas including lift power installation in the foyer, relocating transformer boxes, adding step lights to the media platform, adjustments to bedrooms’ wiring and vents, verifying kitchen shut off valve, moving pantry light switch, and vacuuming walls before insulation/drywall.
- A 1-inch water meter was installed, hitting a Google fiber line accidentally. Brookhaven officials required a ROW permit for future installs. A permit number (AP3164761) was noted.
- Yanes Electrical completed multiple tasks including cove lighting installation, electrical panel setup, and various light and outlet adjustments.
- Deliveries included Brazilian IPE wood and a dumpster drop, with coordination around unloading and placement.
- A tile placement walkthrough with Freddy and Jeffrey took place, discussing detailed tile layouts for bathrooms and other areas.
- Overhang metal roof and custom drip edge installation were completed.
- Solar pipe boot seal and roof cap installation by Patric were done.
- Focus on cleaning and site organization, including scaffolding removal on the side yard and plans for salt fence installation next week.

This summary is based on Slack messages and no conflicting info was found in other sources.

**Sources:** Slack messages from 5/1/2025 and related dates (including Ron Heller’s notes and Thomas’s updates).

what project can I ask you about

You can ask me about a wide range of homebuilding and construction projects, such as:

- Building a new house or addition
- Renovating or remodeling rooms (kitchen, bathroom, basement, etc.)
- Installing or repairing roofing, siding, or flooring
- Plumbing, electrical, or HVAC work
- Landscaping and outdoor structures (decks, patios, fences)
- Energy efficiency upgrades and insulation
- Interior design and finishing touches

Feel free to ask about any specific project you're planning or interested in, and I can provide guidance, tips, and information!

Drywall completion is expected to be approximately 3 weeks from this week, with drywall starting by Friday or Saturday of this week.  

Additionally, drywall cannot start until all insulation punch list items are completed and reviewed, and the insulation inspection passes. The insulation work is actively being finalized with punch lists targeted for completion Monday, and the insulation inspection has been scheduled accordingly.

summaries.content:
1293 Sylvian – Weekly Summary • Week 2025-W18 – Week Ending April 29, 2025

  1. Key Achievements
    • Second floor walls and ceiling spray foam insulation complete over bedrooms.
    • First floor spray foam insulation started and ongoing.
    • Terrace level closed cell foam insulation completed.
    • Open cell foam insulation started on the ceiling of the third level.
    • Batt insulation installed between levels 1 and 2 ceilings per change order #16.
    • Drywall upgraded to 5/8" thickness as paid by client.
  2. Issues or Blockers
    • Insulation subcontractors left windows open in bedrooms one and two and the back door slider, causing dryness issues.
    • Clip boxes were stored in the office garage without labeling or notifying staff.
    • Only one shipping label available for returning clip boxes causing coordination delays.
  3. Upcoming Work
    • Insulation subcontractors to complete spray foam and batt insulation within the next two days.
    • Return of clips using received shipping label pending coordination.
  4. Action Items
    • Omar and Edgar to ensure windows and doors are secured during insulation work.
    • Insulation team to label and communicate storage locations for materials delivered to site.
    • Team member to coordinate return shipment of clips using Nicole’s provided shipping label.
    • Ron and team to conduct inspection of insulation progress onsite as planned.

Daily Summary - 1293 Sylvian Homebuilding Project

1) Key Achievements

  • Terrace level fully completed with closed-cell foam insulation.
  • Work commenced on open-cell foam insulation for the third-level ceiling.
  • Obtained confirmation that three additional shipping labels are being arranged.

2) Issues or Blockers

  • Shipping label management for returning materials is unclear, with only one label available for four boxes containing clips.
  • Potential need to consolidate multiple boxes into a single shipment to comply with label constraints.

3) Upcoming Work

  • Continue applying open-cell foam insulation on the third-level ceiling.
  • Resolve shipping label issues to facilitate efficient return of clips and materials.

4) Action Items

  • Follow up with Nicolle on status of the three additional shipping labels.
  • Determine whether clips can be consolidated into one box for return shipment.
  • Coordinate with the office team to manage and track shipping labels and return logistics.

1293 Sylvian Homebuilding Project

Week-to-Date Summary: May 5 - May 7

1) Key Achievements

  • Client-approved upgrade to 5/8" drywall has been confirmed and noted for installation.
  • Change orders related to insulation finalized:
    • CO #16: Installation of batt insulation in the ceiling between levels 1 and 2.
    • CO #06: Application of spray foam insulation on all exterior walls and ceilings; batt insulation within interior walls; rockwool installed at bedroom #4 bathroom wall and around sewer pipes.
  • A&G delivered clips to the site; however, proper labeling and communication protocols are being reinforced.
  • Return label received from Nicole Brazilian Lumber for clip materials being sent back, facilitating material returns.

2) Issues or Blockers

  • Only one shipping label currently available for some incoming or outgoing materials, causing potential logistics delays.
  • Materials (clips) placed in garage upon delivery without notification or labeling, causing confusion in inventory management.

3) Upcoming Work

  • Installation of upgraded 5/8" drywall per client specification.
  • Completion of insulation work as per change orders #16 and #06 focusing on ceiling, exterior walls, interior walls and specific areas like bedroom #4 bathroom wall.
  • Processing of returned clip materials to Nicole Brazilian Lumber.

4) Action Items

  • Ensure all incoming materials are clearly labeled and communicated to site personnel upon delivery to avoid confusion (responsible: Site Coordinator).
  • Procure additional shipping labels to facilitate smooth material handling and logistics coordination.
  • Supervise and confirm proper installation of upgraded drywall and insulation per change orders.
  • Track return shipment of clip materials utilizing the provided return label (responsible: Procurement Team).

Week-to-Date Summary: 1293 Sylvian Homebuilding Project (May 5 - May 7)

1) Key Achievements

  • Client confirmed upgrade to 5/8" drywall throughout the home.
  • Change orders for insulation finalized and acknowledged:
    • #16: Batt insulation installed in ceiling between levels 1 and 2.
    • #06: Comprehensive insulation scope including foam on all exterior walls and ceilings, batt insulation for interior walls, and rockwool in specific areas (bedroom #4 bathroom wall and around sewer pipes).
  • A&G delivered boxes of clips to the office, although initial misplacement occurred.

2) Issues or Blockers

  • Only one shipping label was initially available for returns, causing some delays.
  • A&G placed clips in the garage without notification or labeling, leading to potential confusion on-site.

3) Upcoming Work

  • Return of surplus clips to Brazilian Lumber utilizing the provided return label found on the project manager’s desk.
  • Ensuring proper labeling and communication of material deliveries moving forward to avoid on-site disorganization.

4) Action Items

  • Reinforce with delivery teams and subcontractors the importance of notifying staff and labeling materials upon delivery.
  • Coordinate with Nicole at Brazilian Lumber to complete the clip return shipment promptly.
  • Confirm receipt and accuracy of all shipping labels for upcoming returns or deliveries.

1293 Sylvian Homebuilding Project: Week-to-Date Summary (May 5 - May 7)

1) Key Achievements

  • Upgraded to 5/8" drywall as per client request has been confirmed and documented.
  • Insulation change orders finalized:
    • CO#16: Batt insulation installed in ceiling between levels 1 & 2.
    • CO#06: Exterior walls and ceilings equipped with foam insulation; interior walls receive batt insulation; Rockwool installed at bedroom #4 bathroom wall and around sewer pipes.
  • A&G delivered boxes of clips to the office, initially placed in the garage.

2) Issues or Blockers

  • Miscommunication regarding delivery of clips: boxes were placed in the garage without notification or labeling.
  • Only one shipping label available for clip returns caused uncertainty in logistics.

3) Upcoming Work

  • Return process for surplus clips underway; return label received from Brazilian Lumber for shipment.
  • Ensure proper labeling and communication protocols are reinforced with suppliers and subcontractors regarding deliveries.

4) Action Items

  • Confirm receipt and correct placement of insulation materials per change orders on site.
  • Coordinate with A&G to ensure all deliveries are labeled and communicated to site management prior to unloading.
  • Implement improved tracking of shipping labels to avoid delays in returns and logistics.

give me an update for any outstanding items over the last ten days

Based on activity over the last ten days, here are the outstanding or in-progress items:

1. Drywall sanding and touch-ups are ongoing, with drywall guys working through today and sanding scheduled to finish this afternoon.
2. Joel Yanes' team is still on-site completing punchlist items and finishing electrical trim; they will tidy the house for flooring to begin Wednesday (May 21).
3. Flooring is scheduled to start May 19-24, directly after painting which is ongoing through May 17.
4. Cabinetry by Dimitri and Christian is in progress, expected ready by mid to end of next week (around May 22-24).
5. Countertops templating will follow cabinet install, scheduled for June 9-16.
6. Plumbing trim and electrical trim are planned for June 17-24.
7. Dumpster swap requested by end of day Monday.
8. Drainage quote and order for materials requested but not yet confirmed.
9. Attic door for garage still needed/ordered (laundry attic door delivered already).
10. Retaining wall approach for pole barn pending final input.

No overdue or upcoming tasks are flagged in Asana for permitting or purchasing.

Summary: Drywall finishing and electrical punchlist with Joel's crew, flooring preparation, cabinetry production, drainage quote/order, and remaining attic door are key outstanding/current focus areas.

If you want updates on any specific item, please let me know! 

(Slack messages, May 13-18, 2025)

4846 Adams – Weekly Summary • Week 2025-W18 – Week Ending April 29, 2025

  1. Key Achievements
    • Cabinet installation progressed, with Dimitri’s team working on finishing up the install.
    • Register installation is in progress with Behrouz’s team.
    • Christian prepared to start installation and punch list work on-site tomorrow.
    • Electrical work scheduled to start Wednesday.
  2. Issues or Blockers
    • Cabana and upstairs secondary bath vanities need height adjustments to 35".
    • “Her” closet cabinets finished in grey instead of the intended Iron Ore color.
    • Gym accent wall requires repainting to Iron Ore.
    • Foyer ceiling primed incorrectly for Iron Ore instead of standard white.
    • Missing wall block, geo grid, block, and sand mortar for the pool area causing delays.
    • Waiting on countertop templates from fabricator to proceed with slab delivery coordination.
    • Retaining wall start date not yet determined.
  3. Upcoming Work
    • Electrical work to commence on Wednesday.
    • Christian scheduled to install and address punch list items starting tomorrow.
    • Continued cabinet install completion likely Thursday or Friday.
    • Measurement and fabrication related to countertops pending completion of cabinet install.
  4. Action Items
    • Dimitri’s team to complete cabinet installs and finalize countertop templates by tomorrow.
    • Project manager to provide updated project timeline to homeowner.
    • Confirm start date for retaining wall construction.
    • Correct painting discrepancies on gym accent wall and foyer ceiling as specified.
    • Follow up on missing materials for pool wall to avoid further delays.

what happened yesterday?

Yesterday at the 6265 Ferry site, several key activities and updates happened:

- Joel Yanes attempted to install the vanity but did not finish, noting it requires two people. He plans to return tomorrow afternoon to complete it.
- Raul and his team were on-site working; however, Raul was at the shop during the day and is scheduled to install remaining cabinets tomorrow.
- The powder room faucet and an adjustable P-trap for plumbing trim are still outstanding, though expected to arrive soon.
- Vilma's crew came to re-measure after shelves returned and took fireplace slabs back for re-cutting related to shelves.
- Eric and his team were on-site performing testing and adjusting registers in the mudroom.
- A&G cleaned the home and organized materials, also covering countertops to protect them.
- Flooring in the powder room was reportedly finished by Ivan's crew.
- Some electrical trim work started with Carlos’ team.
- Appliances were moved to the garage, with installation planned soon but not yet completed.
- Discussions continued about coordinating electrical outlet placements, vent movements in the mudroom, and scheduling plywood board installation.
- The flooring under the vanity needs to be completed before vanity installation to avoid damage.
- Homeowners approved the heights for gas lanterns, which were being installed.
- The fireplace slab installation was delayed due to missing living room shelves but is active in planning.

Overall, progress was made on cabinetry, electrical trim, cleaning, and prep work, but some finishing tasks like vanity installation and plumbing trim await parts and coordination.

**Source:** Slack messages dated 5/5/2025.

How much did we spend on interior paint?

The actual spending on interior paint-related materials is recorded in these Slack entries:

- Home Depot purchases for painting materials:
  - $60.59 for painting material
  - $60.24 for caulking painting
  - $61.93 for paper/plastic painting
- Home Depot Visa charge:
  - $405.83 for material for door installation and painting
- American Best Value:
  - $108.44 for painters (likely labor cost related to painting)
- Hotel expenses for painters:
  - $108.44 twice ($216.88 total), which supports painters on site

Summing the likely interior paint materials alone (from Home Depot) is $60.59 + $60.24 + $61.93 = $182.76.

If you include the $405.83 charge that includes painting material (but also door installation, so not fully paint-related) plus painter labor and hotel, the subtotal goes much higher, but only the $182.76 is clearly dedicated to paint materials.

Please specify if you want only paint materials or total painting-related costs including labor and related expenses.

- Materials clearly for paint: $182.76 (Home Depot)
- Additional related expenses (labor, hotel, other materials) exist but are mixed with other items.

what happened last week

Last week, several activities and updates occurred on the 1320 Mayfair project:

1. **Site Work and Deliveries**: The pavers team was on site, and more pavers and 89 stone were scheduled for delivery. The driveway prep was in progress, and the installation of pervious pavers was ongoing.

2. **Inspections and Reports**: The drywall team was working on sanding and finishing imperfections in the ceiling. Additionally, there was a focus on ensuring that the HVAC units were prepped for installation.

3. **Security Incident**: There was a report of a theft involving a Bosch chip hammer valued at $255, which was stolen from a nearby site. A police report was filed, and security measures were being discussed, including relocating cameras.

4. **Material Arrivals**: There were inquiries about the arrival of sliding door materials and Dekton slabs, with updates indicating that the materials were being fabricated.

5. **Team Coordination**: Various team members were assigned tasks, including spray painting gas lines and ensuring that specific materials were delivered and installed.

6. **Budget Tracking**: The project budget was being monitored, with actual costs reported at $801,185.52 against a total budget of $1,050,000.

For more detailed information on specific tasks or expenses, please let me know!

So, the budgeted amount for TPO roofing material is $13,200.00 as part of the Roofing/House Wrap line item.

**Source:** “1320 Mayfair Budget.xlsx, 1320 Mayfair sheet, row 14”
What was the actual spend amount?

The actual spend amount to date for the 1320 Mayfair project is $801,185.52.

This figure is the total actual cost recorded in the budget spreadsheet under the "1320 Mayfair" sheet (cell Q4) and is confirmed in the "Bank Balance Check" sheet as the expenses from budget actual (cell C37).

If you need a breakdown by category or more details, please let me know!
What was the actual spend amount only related to TPO?

The actual spend amount related to TPO (Thermoplastic Olefin roofing) can be found in the "Input" sheet under the category "Roofing/House Wrap" with notes referencing TPO or related payments.

The relevant TPO-related expenses recorded are:

- Heely Brown TPO: $18,393.97 on 2024-11-13
- Refund Heely Brown Roofing (negative): -$3,593.70 on 2024-11-18
- Scapegoat Systems LLC TPO deposit: $2,500.00 on 2024-11-13
- Scapegoat Systems LLC TPO: $6,300.00 on 2024-11-26
- Heely Brown TPO: $344.89 on 2024-11-26
- Division TPO: $104.69 on 2024-12-03
- Heely Brown TPO: $2,424.66 on 2025-01-22
- Correct House Wrap: $3,675.00 on 2024-11-21 (likely related to TPO correction)
- Heely Brown Sealant: $157.37 on 2024-12-10 (likely related to TPO)
- Scapegoat Systems LLC TPO related: $550.00 on 2025-02-07
- Correct House Wrap: $350.00 on 2024-12-30
- Various very small amounts related to roofing included above may also relate to TPO.

Calculating the net sum of the major TPO amounts:

18,393.97 (Heely Brown TPO)
- 3,593.70 (Refund)
+ 2,500.00 (Scapegoat deposit)
+ 6,300.00 (Scapegoat TPO)
+ 344.89 (Heely Brown TPO)
+ 104.69 (Division TPO)
+ 2,424.66 (Heely Brown TPO)
+ 3,675.00 (Correct House Wrap)
+ 157.37 (Heely Brown Sealant)
+ 550.00 (Scapegoat TPO)
+ 350.00 (Correct House Wrap)

Total = 31,706.88 USD approximately

Therefore, the actual spend amount related to TPO is approximately $31,706.88.

This aligns with the "Roofing/House Wrap" actual cost line of $33,908.42 in the 1320 Mayfair sheet (some related roof costs may not be TPO).

Let me know if you want a detailed transaction list or breakdown.

Summary:
**TPO actual spend ≈ $31,706.88** based on expense entries in the Input sheet related to "Roofing/House Wrap" and TPO notes.

(Sources: "1320 Mayfair Budget.xlsx", Input sheet; "1320 Mayfair Budget.xlsx", 1320 Mayfair sheet)

messages.content: what happened last week?

Last week, several activities took place at the 1253 Mayfair project site:

1. On April 24, 2025, Taka Shigematsu and Yakir Zaken adjusted the window and exterior door plans, which were then sent to Luz for updates. Dennis Trepanier reported that the T-pole inspection failed due to the absence of a grounding rod.

2. By April 28, 2025, Seminole Concrete had finished the forms, and the team was waiting for kitchen layout plans from Ron Z before the plumber could start on Wednesday. Ron Heller mentioned that the plumber would be scheduled for Wednesday, followed by an inspection, with the slab expected to be completed by the end of the next week.

3. On April 29, 2025, Ron Heller confirmed that Seminole had completed the box forms, and the site was ready for the plumber. Joel completed the ground rod installation, and Dennis Trepanier scheduled the T-pole for Wednesday.

The team is actively coordinating to ensure that all necessary components are in place for the next phase of construction, according to Ron Heller and Dennis Trepanier on April 28 and 29, 2025.

messages.content: what is the current status here?

The current status of the 1253 Mayfair project is as follows:

- Footing inspection is still pending and must be approved before slab inspection can proceed. The footing inspection has not yet been completed.
- Underslab plumbing is in progress and the underslab inspection was scheduled, but the underslab inspection was canceled because footing inspection approval is required first.
- Plumbing prep is ongoing, including a change from 2x4 to 2x6 framing.
- Survey and foundation-related approvals for footing and foundation survey are pending.
- Exterior doors and sliders sizes are being finalized, and CAD drawings and window estimates from Home Depot are awaited.
- T-pole inspection was initially scheduled but failed due to no grounding rod; a reinspection and temp power request to Georgia Power are needed.
- Pre-construction inspections have passed, and grading, house corner staking, and loading of gravel are underway.
- Many permit approvals are completed, but some trade permits and inspections such as footing, underslab plumbing, foundation survey, foundation wall, slab inspection, gas line, and others are still outstanding in the permitting project.
- No overdue or upcoming tasks are noted in Asana projects for both the main build and permitting.

In summary, the site is currently waiting on footing inspection approval to proceed with slab-related work and further inspections. Plumbing prep and grading are active, and exterior window/door details and permits are being finalized.

**Main pending actions:**
- Schedule and pass footing inspection and foundation survey
- Complete underslab plumbing and slab inspections
- Address t-pole inspection issues and secure temporary power
- Finalize door/window CAD drawings and estimates

This status is from the latest Slack messages and Asana permit task checklist.  

Let me know if you need details on any specific item.
when will the slab be poured?

The slab pour at 1253 Mayfair is planned for the end of next week. The sequence includes completing the footing inspection and foundation survey approval before the slab inspection can take place. Plumbing prep and under-slab plumbing inspections are in progress, but the footing inspection still needs to happen first. Once the plumber completes the prep and the inspections are scheduled and passed, the slab concrete pour can proceed, targeted around the end of next week.

Reference details:
- "We have still not had a footing and will need to have foundation survey approved before the slab inspection."
- "Ron said he was gonna work on the kitchen cabinet plans... Should have slab by end of next week."
- Plumbing prep and under slab inspections are scheduled and ongoing.
- Footing inspection is pending and required before slab inspections.

All of the above indicate slab pouring is expected after footing approval and scheduled for the end of next week.  

(Slack, 2025-05-12)

messages.content: Can you summarize any outstanding tasks and issues for me

Based on the latest Slack messages and Asana project data for 195 Pebble Trail, here is a summary of outstanding tasks and current issues:

1. **Outstanding Tasks & Coordination Needs:**
   - Fireplace delivery and installation scheduled; framing and materials need verification.
   - Installation of wall mount toilets and free standing tub rough-ins requires coordination with plumber and framers (Pepe and Brandon).
   - Stucco selection and pricing confirmed at $46,000, but installation quote and timing pending final coordination.
   - TPO roofing and skylight installation mostly complete; final membrane completion and walkthroughs (including electrical with Yanes) need scheduling.
   - Window delivery is expected; coordination for installation post Tyvec (house wrap) is ongoing.
   - Cabinet plans need updates, especially for powder room and various vanity sizes.
   - Balcony drainage issue resolved but requires follow-up on steel beam constraints affecting the master bath water closet design.
   - Patio drains and slopes require review and finalizing.
   - Tub protector ordered but needs to be confirmed and delivered.
   - Dumpster swap scheduled for Wednesday.
   - Scheduling meeting times onsite for soffit and rainscreen measurements, plumbing walkthroughs, and patio details.
   - Coordination for Anderson window delivery and inventory needed.

2. **Issues and Challenges:**
   - Two missing windows causing delivery and installation delays; logistics with CDS being worked out.
   - Master bath toilet plumbing obstructed by a steel beam with no option to cut through; redesign required per engineer.
   - Sediment runoff from an adjacent lot (Harwell home) causing rainout issues.
   - Need confirmation that all framing prep for wall mount toilets and niches is complete before proceeding.
   - Need to ensure membrane and house is fully dried before next trades start rough-ins.
   - Potential scheduling challenges with installation crews for windows, doors, and roofing components.

3. **Permit Status:**
   - No overdue or upcoming tasks in permitting Asana project; all foundation, slab, framing, and inspections appear complete or approved.

No overdue or upcoming tasks are listed in Asana, indicating current tasks are in progress and awaiting coordination or deliveries.

If you need details on any specific task or issue, please let me know. 

(Sources: Slack messages from recent logs; Asana project " 195 Pebble Trail" and "[PERMIT] 195 Pebble Trail")

messages.content: what happened yesterday?

Based on the provided messages, here is what happened yesterday:

- There was a theft involving Bosch Chip hammers valued at $255 at 1269 Mayfair, with a police report filed. The back sliding door was suspected to be the entry point, and security cameras were reinstalled after being down.  
- The police are actively investigating, and an inventory list of stolen items is being compiled.  
- The camera at the site was removed and is being relocated to 2387 Poplar.  
- The HVAC team was on their way to prep the AC units, scheduled to drop on Wednesday.  
- The drywall team was sanding and finishing ceiling imperfections.  
- Pavers were being delivered and installed, with backfill and grading in progress in the front yard.  
- Gravel installation was scheduled for tomorrow.  
- The team was working on various site preparations, including fixing the driveway, installing handles and pulls, and preparing for countertop templating.  
- Other ongoing activities included spray painting gas lines, fabricating sliding door materials, installing Dekton slabs, and working on electrical trim and other finishing tasks.

Please let me know if you need more specific details.

chatbot.name: Spark Expense Agent
chatbot.systemPrompt:
You are “Six Points Card ChargeBot”, a finance assistant for Six Points Homes.

SOURCE OF TRUTH  
• You receive only the Slack messages from channel #six-points-card (via MCP Server).  
• Ignore any other context unless explicitly provided.

GOAL  
1. Normal Mode (default): Parse each batch of Slack messages and output a list of every Spark-card charge or refund, following the OUTPUT FORMAT.  
2. Amount-Query Mode: If the user’s entire message is just a dollar amount (e.g., “$142.06” or “142.06”), search the last **7 days** of channel history.  
   • If an **exact amount** match is found, return that expense line (or multiple lines if more than one).  
   • If no exact match exists but you find an expense **within ± $5.00**, return it preceded by “Close match –”.  
   • If nothing is found, reply:  
      No expense matching $X.XX (±$5) was found in the last 7 days.  
   • Use the same Vendor / Amount / Description / Project formatting rules.

PARSING & NORMALISATION  
• If an employee omits the description, use **Material**.  
• Summarise multi-item descriptions briefly (e.g., “Electric Trim, bulbs”).  
• Format all amounts with commas for thousands (e.g., $1,133.39).  
• Refunds: prepend **REFUND** and show a negative amount (e.g., $-274.75).  
• Map vendor nicknames to full names:  
  ─ Home Depot ← HD, HDepot, Home D  
  ─ Lowe’s ← Lowes, lwes  
  ─ Sherwin Williams ← Sherwin, SH, SW  
  ─ Sunset Paint ← Sunset  
  ─ Atlanta Landscaping Material ← ALM, Atlanta Landscaping  
  ─ Brazilian Wood Depot ← Brazilian Wood, BW, Brazilian  
  ─ Floor and Decor ← FND, FD, Floor Decor  
  ─ Stovall ← Stovall  
  If only the vendor appears (e.g., “SH $46”), infer the obvious material (→ paint for Sherwin Williams).

PROJECT NAME RESOLUTION  
• Expand shorthand via the lookup list below (e.g., “2383” → 2383 Poplar).  
• If ambiguous (e.g., “Poplar” alone), set project to **UNKNOWN**.  
• “General Expense” → project **Six Points General**.

PROJECT LOOK-UP LIST  
4846 Adams • 160 Black Ankle • General Expense • 3023 Parkridge • 2367 Cortez • 125 Cromwell • 2688 Drew Valley • 6249 Ferry • 6265 Ferry • 1768 8th St • 1223 Mayfair • 1231 Mayfair • 1269 Mayfair • 1320 Mayfair • 1318 Hopkins • 2363 Nesbitt • 4845 Northway • 1644 Richwood • 2354 Poplar • 2383 Poplar • 2387 Poplar • 2393 Poplar • 2646 Cove • 1028 Citadel • 3197 Saybrook • 3187 Saybrook • 3871 Powers Ferry • 2540 Drew Valley • 2476 Drew Valley • 2461 Thompson • 630 Carriage • 195 Pebble • 2975 Westminster Circle • 2981 Westminster • 911 S Shore • 9157 Dickens • 3582 Avocado • 580 Elmwood • 1293 Sylvan

VALIDATION  
• In Normal Mode, output must follow the template exactly—one charge per line, newline-separated, with **Vendor  Amount  Description  “for”  Project**.  
• In Amount-Query Mode, output only the matching lines (or the close-match line), with no header.  
• Never add extra commentary, markdown, or blank lines.  
• If no matches (Normal Mode) reply:  
  No Spark-card charges were posted in #six-points-card during the specified period.
• Do not append author names, message dates, or any other metadata (e.g., “according to Ron Heller on 4/29/2025”) in either Normal Mode or Amount-Query Mode.
Follow the OUTPUT FORMAT below for all responses.
chatbot.outputFormat:
Normal Mode
------------
See below charges from messages between {{startDate}} and {{endDate}}:
[Vendor] $X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]

chatbot.name: Amex Expense Agent
chatbot.systemPrompt:
You are “Six Points Card ChargeBot”, a finance assistant for Six Points Homes.

SOURCE OF TRUTH  
• You receive only the Slack messages from channel #six-points-card (via MCP Server).  
• Ignore any other context unless explicitly provided.

GOAL  
1. Normal Mode (default): Parse each batch of Slack messages and output a list of every Spark-card charge or refund, following the OUTPUT FORMAT.  
2. Amount-Query Mode: If the user’s entire message is just a dollar amount (e.g., “$142.06” or “142.06”), search the last **7 days** of channel history.  
   • If an **exact amount** match is found, return that expense line (or multiple lines if more than one).  
   • If no exact match exists but you find an expense **within ± $5.00**, return it preceded by “Close match –”.  
   • If nothing is found, reply:  
      No expense matching $X.XX (±$5) was found in the last 7 days.  
   • Use the same Vendor / Amount / Description / Project formatting rules.

PARSING & NORMALISATION  
• If an employee omits the description, use **Material**.  
• Summarise multi-item descriptions briefly (e.g., “Electric Trim, bulbs”).  
• Format all amounts with commas for thousands (e.g., $1,133.39).  
• Refunds: prepend **REFUND** and show a negative amount (e.g., $-274.75).  
• Map vendor nicknames to full names:  
  ─ Home Depot ← HD, HDepot, Home D  
  ─ Lowe’s ← Lowes, lwes  
  ─ Sherwin Williams ← Sherwin, SH, SW  
  ─ Sunset Paint ← Sunset  
  ─ Atlanta Landscaping Material ← ALM, Atlanta Landscaping  
  ─ Brazilian Wood Depot ← Brazilian Wood, BW, Brazilian  
  ─ Floor and Decor ← FND, FD, Floor Decor  
  ─ Stovall ← Stovall  
  If only the vendor appears (e.g., “SH $46”), infer the obvious material (→ paint for Sherwin Williams).

PROJECT NAME RESOLUTION  
• Expand shorthand via the lookup list below (e.g., “2383” → 2383 Poplar).  
• If ambiguous (e.g., “Poplar” alone), set project to **UNKNOWN**.  
• “General Expense” → project **Six Points General**.

PROJECT LOOK-UP LIST  
4846 Adams • 160 Black Ankle • General Expense • 3023 Parkridge • 2367 Cortez • 125 Cromwell • 2688 Drew Valley • 6249 Ferry • 6265 Ferry • 1768 8th St • 1223 Mayfair • 1231 Mayfair • 1269 Mayfair • 1320 Mayfair • 1318 Hopkins • 2363 Nesbitt • 4845 Northway • 1644 Richwood • 2354 Poplar • 2383 Poplar • 2387 Poplar • 2393 Poplar • 2646 Cove • 1028 Citadel • 3197 Saybrook • 3187 Saybrook • 3871 Powers Ferry • 2540 Drew Valley • 2476 Drew Valley • 2461 Thompson • 630 Carriage • 195 Pebble • 2975 Westminster Circle • 2981 Westminster • 911 S Shore • 9157 Dickens • 3582 Avocado • 580 Elmwood • 1293 Sylvan

VALIDATION  
• In Normal Mode, output must follow the template exactly—one charge per line, newline-separated, with **Vendor  Amount  Description  “for”  Project**.  
• In Amount-Query Mode, output only the matching lines (or the close-match line), with no header.  
• Never add extra commentary, markdown, or blank lines.  
• If no matches (Normal Mode) reply:  
  No Spark-card charges were posted in #six-points-card during the specified period.
• Do not append author names, message dates, or any other metadata (e.g., “according to Ron Heller on 4/29/2025”) in either Normal Mode or Amount-Query Mode.
Follow the OUTPUT FORMAT below for all responses.
chatbot.outputFormat:
Normal Mode
------------
See below charges from messages between {{startDate}} and {{endDate}}:
[Vendor] $X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]
[Vendor] $X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]
REFUND [Vendor] $-X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]
…(one line per charge, each ending with a newline)…

Amount-Query Mode
-----------------
[Vendor] $X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]          ← exact match
Close match – [Vendor] $X,XXX.XX [description] for [Project Name]   ← ± $5 match

Last week, several activities took place on the site:

1. **Cooktop Preparation**: The cooktop prep was completed, and the cut for the cooktop was in progress.
2. **Plumbing and Electric Trim**: Plumbing trim was reported as complete, with some led strips still on order. Electric trim was scheduled to be completed early this week.
3. **Cleaning**: A&G was on track to clean the home, and there were plans for the stucco team to clean as well.

6. **Site Visits and Tasks**: Dimitri and another team member were scheduled to walk the house, and there were ongoing discussions about moving materials and scheduling measurements.

Overall, it seems the team was focused on finishing various installations and ensuring the site was cleaned and prepared for the next steps.

what happened last week?

Here’s a summary of what happened last week (April 29–May 5) on 16 Bonnie, based on Slack updates:

• Site cleanup & NOV compliance  
  – Construction materials and sediment were removed from the street per the NOV (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – Pavers and debris were also cleared from the roadway and driveway (Slack, 2025-05-01).  

• Kitchen / cooktop  
  – Prep for the cooktop was completed and the cut-in was in progress (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – The Elbrus/Pitt cooktop was tracked down at the office; coordination underway to have Vilma cut the countertop (Slack, 2025-04-29).  

• Doors & hardware  
  – The stationary door was fixed but its latch was missing; a replacement latch was ordered (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – A sliding-door latch was likewise ordered and is in transit (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

• Floor protection  
  – Gerardex was brought in to cover exposed flooring as a precaution (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

• Trim & finishes  
  – Plumbing trim-out was completed or wrapping up (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – Electric trim walkthrough held; electric trim work is slated to continue early this week (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – LED strips are on order for final trim (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

• Cabinetry & shelving  
  – Secondary closet shelves and cabinet pulls are in production with Christian Cabinetry; installation in master closet scheduled (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

• Cleaning  
  – A&G was on track to clean the home; stucco crew also tasked with cleaning exterior (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

• Walkthroughs & inspections  
  – Dimitri and Aaron conducted a site walk on Wednesday at 1 PM (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – Registers were opened and counts compared to Aaron’s list (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – Paint testing (“Greek Villa” SW-7551) and lime-wash scope reviewed for fireplace, TV wall, staircase, powder room (Slack, 2025-04-29).  

• Logistics & scheduling  
  – Triad scheduled for measurements; Radim’s exterior touch-up timing queried (Slack, 2025-05-01 & 2025-05-05).  
  – Premium Pella items to ship directly from Brennan’s office; shipping updates pending (Slack, 2025-05-05).  
  – Porta-John removal was requested (Slack, 2025-05-05).  

Let me know if you need more detail on any of these items.

give me an update for any outstanding items over the last ten days

Here is an update on outstanding items from the last ten days at the 16 Bonnie project:

1. **Painter (Christian) Issues**:  
   - Christian has been unreliable, missed the last one-year walkthrough, and has not responded to calls or texts.  
   - He is still needed to install registers at 1320 Mayfair and at Bonnie Lane. Christian promised to install the registers on the day of the latest update but had not gone over the weekend before that.  
   - Christian fixed some cabinet issues but still needs to address drawer latch adjustments in the master.  
   - There is a general decision not to rely on Christian anymore due to ongoing issues.

2. **Cooktop Clips**:  
   - Missing two support brackets (clips) for the cooktop; only two came with the unit but four are needed.  
   - Joel's team and Vilma's install team have been involved in communication and action on this issue.

3. **Site Mounds**:  
   - Jaime needs to go ASAP to fix the mounds on the left side of the home towards the neighbor’s side to pass inspection.

4. **Protection & Coverage**:  
   - All fans and light fixtures need to be covered before painting continues. Joel's crew is responsible for covering light fixtures and countertops as they start painting.  
   - Some shelves and the $7,000 stone tub are not adequately covered and must be protected immediately.

5. **Electrical Work Remaining**:  
   - Finish adjustments for dining room fixtures.  
   - Finish bathroom fan plates install.  
   - Fix disposal outlets.  
   - Install outlet for wine bar fridge.  
   - Install 3 exterior can trim lights.  
   - Install outside outlet by front door.  
   - Cover plates and final electrical inspection.

6. **Other Installations & Fixes**:  
   - Sliding door lock and latch have been fixed.  
   - Jim installer is scheduled for latch installation on the sliding door.  
   - Appliances are 95% in; Dimitri is scheduled for cabinet adjustments and fixes.

7. **Inspection & Site Review Comments**:  
   - A stone piece (retaining wall) on the north side needs more height per City inspectors; the note about the wall will be removed from the plan.  
   - Dimension and details for this wall are required to meet setback and property line regulations.

8. **Schedule Notes**:  
   - Joel's team and drywall team are currently on site.  
   - Joel is scheduled to start some work imminently after painters finish.  
   - Rick expects the garage door delivery by May 26.

If you want details on any specific item or the responsible party for follow-up, let me know.

**Source:** Slack messages from May 7 to May 19, 2025.

summaries.content:
16 Bonnie – Weekly Summary • Week 2025-W18 – Week Ending April 29, 2025

  1. Key Achievements
    • Sliding door lock fixed and latch ordered for replacement due to loss.
    • Secondary shelves installed and master closet finishing underway by Christian.
    • Cooktop preparation and cut-in progress completed.
    • Materials including latch dropped off on site and scheduled for installation.
    • Notice of Violation lifted after materials and sediment removal from the street.
    • Final trim out and appliance installation scheduled to start Monday and Tuesday.
    • Home cleaning scheduled with A&G and stucco team coordination for cleanup.
    • Walkthrough of the house conducted by Dimitri and project lead.
    • Stationary door repaired successfully despite latch being lost and reordered.
  2. Issues or Blockers
    • Discrepancy in opening size for wine bar fridge; measurement and fitting under review.
    • Sliding door latch material delivery status unclear; follow-up needed.
    • Challenges with low-voltage contractor on pricing and scheduling.
    • Touch-up work missed during late-week visits requiring photographic proof for correction.
  3. Upcoming Work
    • Jim to install sliding door latch Friday morning.
    • Christian to continue installing secondary shelves and cabinet pulls with trim in master bedroom tomorrow.
    • Joel to start final trim out and appliance installation early next week.
    • Max scheduled to complete electrical trim out tomorrow.

chatbot.name: Bookhaven Municipal Codes
chatbot.systemPrompt:
You are a compliance assistant trained specifically to help users understand and follow the City of Brookhaven, Georgia’s Code of Ordinances as it applies to residential home building. Your primary role is to provide accurate, thorough, and helpful answers based on the knowledge base of up-to-date code documents provided to you. Always prioritize information from the knowledge base over your general training or assumptions. Do not rely on your own knowledge if the knowledge base has relevant material.

When responding to questions, always:

Refer to specific language from the code whenever possible.

Cite exact sections using the format: Sec. 7-121. (a) or Sec. 14-205. (b)(2) whenever a specific ordinance applies.

Use quotation marks when quoting or closely paraphrasing official ordinance text.

Be clear and professional—avoid legal jargon when simpler phrasing will help the user take action.

If you find multiple relevant code sections, mention all of them clearly.

If no relevant information is found in the knowledge base, respond with:
“I couldn’t find that in the current version of the Brookhaven Code available to me. Please consult the city’s official planning department or website for confirmation.”

Your top priorities are:

Accuracy

Citing source sections

Clarity in plain language

Examples of proper citation:

“According to Sec. 27-733. (c), ‘Accessory structures must be located a minimum of five feet from the rear lot line.’”

“Permit requirements are listed in Sec. 7-121. (a).”

Never guess or generalize if specific guidance is available. Always rely on the provided ordinance text files as your source of truth.
